nodes.bodyText: getLocalPrincipal() should not be null when getLocalCertificates() is not null.
Consider returning a constant
Consider defining serialVersionUID
If the arguments is false, should we also clear existing sessionCache?
isProtocolEnabled and isCipherSuiteEnabled may be static
Consider also verifying that the session was reused.
this will be reverted before merge
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -354,9 +354,9 @@
     <osmaven.version>1.6.2</osmaven.version>
     <!-- keep in sync with PlatformDependent#ALLOWED_LINUX_OS_CLASSIFIERS -->
     <os.detection.classifierWithLikes>fedora,suse,arch</os.detection.classifierWithLikes>
-    <tcnative.artifactId>netty-tcnative</tcnative.artifactId>
-    <tcnative.version>2.0.30.Final</tcnative.version>

+    <tcnative.artifactId>netty-tcnative-boringssl-static</tcnative.artifactId>

nodes.bodyText: Looks like it should be opposite: drain only if new size < oldSize.

When timeout is changed some sessions may become invalidated and should be removed from the cache.
We can do this as a follow-up, let's just keep a reminder somewhere.
the timeout should only affect new sessions as stated in the javadocs of SSLSessionContext
https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/javax/net/ssl/SSLSessionContext.html#setSessionTimeout(int)
The freeSeessions() method does the same thing as expungeInvalidSessions() (except synchronized). Consider reusing the logic that clears sessions.
it does not the same as exponugeInvalidSessions also takes isValid into account

Why only positive numbers? Zero is also a legit value.
Negative values should throw an IllegalArgumetException, consider verifying input parameters from public API of SslContextBuilder or OpenSslClientContext ctors.
Consider clarifying the current and expected values in the exception message.
Consider clarifying the current and expected values in the exception message.

Same comment as for the client:


Why only positive numbers? Zero is also a legit value.
Negative values should throw an IllegalArgumetException, consider verifying input parameters from public API of SslContextBuilder or OpenSslClientContext ctors.


Does that mean that we have an external cache for the server side as well?
yes... we use the same "mechanism" for client and server.

IIRC the session reuse for TLSv1.3 should work in the same was as session id from the OpenSSL API point of view, only time of receiving PSK is different. Are you going to work on session resumption for TLSv1.3 in a follow-up?
it already works... I just need to come up with a unit test as you can not assume the session is sent when the handshake completes.
If this a ref-counted object, should retain() also perform io.netty.internal.tcnative.SSLSession.upRef?
nope... We only reference count the java object itself to simplify things here.
Accidental move :)
Btw, should we enable tickets by default when users specify TLSv1.3 version in the list of protocols? That will be more inline with JDK.
good question... is this the case for TLSv1.3 in JDK ?
With JDK provider tickets just work when users specify TLSv1.3 protocol. No additional configuration is necessary.
ok ... done
If you use equalsIgnoreCase here, the host.hashCode() should also ignore case.
Good catch...
This methods may invoke freeSessions() internally. In all other cases you protect the freeSessions with write lock. Do we need a lock here as well?
freeSessions() is defined as synchronized is this not good enough ?
missed that, 👍
Should we throw if the requested sessionCacheSize/sessionTimeout  is higher than Integer.MAX_VALUE? Or at least log it? Silent override may be confusing.
this is the same code we use for the JDK implementation. Let me think about it and make a follow up if needed to keep it consistent.
Can we verify that a single session available in cache is reused for a.netty.io?
IIRC, assertions work only from the main thread in junit. You need to store the result in something like integer holder / atomic-integer and then assert from the main thread.
if this fails it would fail the test as we would never write back to the client. That said let me store it in an AtomicReference so it would produce more detail if it failed.
I probably miss it somewhere, but how do you know if the session was reused via session ticket, not session id for TLSv1.2?
should this be a defensive copy?
nope as we not re-use it later on. Let me add a comment.
defensive copy?
same comment as above... this will never be mutated.
